Asset File: 
explore_fairs_and_markets.pdf
item.dc:creator: JeanM

item.title: Overton Markets and Fairs
item.description:
This article traces the history of the fairs and markets from 1218 to the present day, including the commodities traded, how the markets were regulated and the revenues due to the Bishop of Winchester as lord of the manor.

In the 19th century, the annual sheep fair was moved from the main street to a more convenient field and the local gentry formed an ‘Overton Sheep Fair Society’ with prizes for the best entries and a sumptuous dinner. Both initiatives resulted in a substantial increase in business with up to 100,000 animals changing hands. As with all the country fairs, however, the coming of the railways eventually resulted in its demise, as the sellers moved their sheep by rail to the major cities where prices were higher. The associated pleasure fair was revived in 2000. It is held every four years and attracts thousands of visitors.
item.dc:creator: JeanM

item.title: Dunster's potteries and brickworks
item.description:
Asset Author: 
Mary Siraut / Mary Siraut
Copyright: 
University of London

Potter and Crocker surnames occur between 1266 and 1375 and Crokkerlane in 1417, implying the existence of a medieval pottery. Pottery was being made in Dunster in the 20th century but the industry was particularly important in the 18th century when brickmaking also started on an industrial scale.

Asset File: 
dunster_potteries_and_brickworks.doc
item.dc:creator: MaryS

item.title: Longrun Farm and Whipples Mill
item.description:
Copyright: 
University of London

The area covered by the present Longrun Meadow public open space did not form part of Longrun farm until after the mid 19th century but was shared between several holdings. The name first appears in the late 18th century.

 

Until the 1820s there were two homesteads in the area, the second being a mill house with a mill.

 

Asset File: 
longrun_and_whipples_mill.doc
item.dc:creator: MaryS

item.title: Remains of millpond, Longrun, Bishops Hull
item.description:
Willow Cathedral, Longrun, Bishops Hull
Copyright: 
Mary Siraut, University of London

Bishops Hull was once home to a large number of both grain and fulling mills, which have been lost. This partly dried up millpond has managed to survive for about two centuries since the demolition of the mill

Asset File: 
p1120048.jpg
item.dc:creator: MaryS

item.title: Longrun and Whipples Mill
item.description: Longrun with its former farmstead is well known to dog walkers, runners, young people and others but the millpond is hidden and nearly dry and all trace of the mill has disappeared. The former medieval fields and meadows now form part of a large public open space between Taunton and Bishops Hull village in the floodplain of the river Tone known for its willow cathedral.
item.dc:creator: MaryS

item.title: Manorial accounts, 1338-9
item.description:
Copyright: 
CLHS

This transcript was prepared by the Latin Group of the Cheltenham Local History Society in 2016.  It is taken from a single roll, preserved in the Berkeley Castle Muniments, and relates to a Berkeley holding in Leckhampton, acquired some time after 1300.

item.title: Lutterworth Market
item.description:
Lutterworth Market
Asset Author: 
Pam Fisher / Pam Fisher
Copyright: 
Pam Fisher
Asset File: 
lutterworth_market.jpg
item.dc:creator: PamF

item.title: The Retail Trade in Lutterworth
item.description:
Lutterworth's market charter was granted in 1214. A fresh charter was obtained in 1414 for both the market and an annual fair, held on the eve and day of the Ascension. A survey of 1509 shows that specialist market areas had appeared: the Neats Market for the sale of young cattle, 'le Fleshamills' for butchers and a Woodmarket, one of the widest streets in the west of the town. By 1607 the Neats Market had been joined by a Beast Market, a 'Shepemarket', a 'Cornemarkett', an Iron Market and a Drapery.   

Permament shops had also emerged by the 17th century, some selling just one product, for example, hats, but also large general stores (perhaps only one at any one time), selling cloth, groceries and a small number of household items, including writing paper and arsenic.   

By 1790 the market was said to be of 'no great note', and the livestock element suffered a fatal blow when the railway failed to come to the town until 1899.

A small weekly market is still held in 2015 in the market square by the 1836 Town Hall. Shops line the High Street, but the main shopping area is along Church Street. Like many small market towns, most of the shops are independently owned.
item.dc:creator: PamF
